sen.j: 松平 宗秀（本庄宗秀、あるいは本荘宗秀とも）（まつだいら むねひで、文化 (元号)6年9月13日 (旧暦)（1809年10月21日） - 明治6年（1873年）12月20日）は、江戸時代幕末の大名、老中。
sen.e: Munehide MATSUDAIRA [or Munehide HONJO (本庄宗秀 or本荘宗秀)], [September 13, 1809 on lunar calendar (October 21, 1809) - December 20, 1873] was a feudal lord, and Roju (the highest ranking government official) in the end of Edo era.

Munehide MATSUDAIRA [or Munehide HONJO (本庄宗秀 or本荘宗秀)], [September 13, 1809 on lunar calendar (October 21, 1809) - December 20, 1873] was a feudal lord, and Roju (the highest ranking government official) in the end of Edo era.
Munehide MATSUDAIRA, or Munehide HONJO (October 21, 1809 - December 20, 1873) was a feudal lord, and Roju (the highest ranking government official) in the end of Edo era.
sen.cmt: 漢字の表記は不要と考え削除しました。新暦に訂正しました。

sen.j: 丹後国宮津藩第6代藩主。
sen.e: The sixth lord of Miyazu Domain, Tango Province
The sixth lord of Miyazu Domain, Tango Province
The sixth lord of Miyazu Domain, Tango Province.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 本庄松平家9代。
sen.e: The ninth generation of the Honjo-Matsudaira family
The ninth generation of the Honjo-Matsudaira family
The sixth lord of Miyazu Domain, Tango Province.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 4代藩主・松平宗允の三男。
sen.e: He was the third son of Munetada MATSUDAIRA who was the fourth lord of domain.
He was the third son of Munetada MATSUDAIRA who was the fourth lord of domain.
He was the third son of Munetada MATSUDAIRA who was the fourth lord of domain.

sen.j: 正室は松平乗全の娘、継室は大久保忠真の娘、継々室は松平輝延の娘。
sen.e: His legal wife was a daughter of Noriyasu MATSUDAIRA, his second wife was a daughter of Tadazane OKUBO, his third wife was a daughter of Terunobu MATSUDAIRA.
His legal wife was a daughter of Noriyasu MATSUDAIRA, his second wife was a daughter of Tadazane OKUBO, his third wife was a daughter of Terunobu MATSUDAIRA.
His legal wife was a daughter of Noriyasu MATSUDAIRA, his second wife was a daughter of Tadazane OKUBO, his third wife was a daughter of Terunobu MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 子は牧野忠訓（四男、越後長岡藩牧野家養子）、松平宗武（五男）、朽木綱鑑（七男、旧福知山朽木子爵家養子）、娘（富田知興室）。
sen.e: His sons were Tadakuni MAKINO (his fourth son, adopted son to the Makino family in the Echigo-Nagaoka Domain), Munetake MATSUDAIRA (his fifth son), Kokan KUCHIKI (his seventh son, adopted son to the viscount Kuchiki family in former Fukuchiyama Domain), his daughter was Tomooki TOMITA's wife.

His sons were Tadakuni MAKINO (his fourth son, adopted son to the Makino family in the Echigo-Nagaoka Domain), Munetake MATSUDAIRA (his fifth son), Kokan KUCHIKI (his seventh son, adopted son to the viscount Kuchiki family in former Fukuchiyama Domain), his daughter was Tomooki TOMITA's wife.

His sons were Tadakuni MAKINO (his fourth son, adopted son to the Makino family in Nagaoka Domain of Echigo Province), Munetake MATSUDAIRA (his fifth son), Kokan KUCHIKI (his seventh son, adopted son to the viscount Kuchiki family in former Fukuchiyama Domain), his daughter was Tomooki TOMITA's wife.
sen.cmt: Echigo-Nagaoka DomainをNagaoka Domain of Echigo Provinceと訂正しました。

sen.j: 幼名は秀次郎。
sen.e: His childhood name was Hidejiro.
His childhood name was Hidejiro.
His childhood name was Hidejiro.

sen.j: 官位は従四位下侍従、図書頭・丹波国守・伯耆国守。
sen.e: His official career was Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Jiju (chamberlain), Zusho no kami (Chief of the Bureau of Books and Drawings), Tanba no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Tanba), Hoki no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Hoki).

His official career was Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Jiju (chamberlain), Zusho no kami (Chief of the Bureau of Books and Drawings), Tanba no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Tanba), Hoki no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Hoki).

His official career was Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Jiju (chamberlain), Zusho no kami (Chief of the Bureau of Books and Drawings), Tanba no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Tanba), Hoki no kuni no kami (Provincial Governor of Hoki).

sen.j: 父・宗允死去後、宗秀は幼少だったため、叔父の松平宗発を挟んで、天保11年（1840年）に宮津藩を相続した。
sen.e: When his father Munetada died, Munehide was infant and his uncle Muneakira MATSUDAIRA inherited the Miyazu Domain, then Muneakira inherited it.
When his father Munetada died, Munehide was an infant and his uncle Muneakira MATSUDAIRA inherited the Miyazu Domain after which Muneakira inherited it.
When his father Munetada died, Munehide was an infant and his uncle Muneakira MATSUDAIRA inherited the Miyazu Domain after which Muneakira inherited it.

sen.j: 大老井伊直弼の元で寺社奉行として安政の大獄を行政化し、その後大坂城代を経る。
sen.e: He carried out the Ansei no taigoku (Ansei Purge) as Jisha bugyo (magistrate of temples) under Tario (chief minister) Naosuke II, then he became Osaka jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He carried out the Ansei no taigoku (Ansei Purge) as Jisha bugyo (magistrate of temples) under Tario (chief minister) Naosuke II, then became Osaka jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle).
He carried out the Ansei no taigoku (Ansei Purge) as Jisha bugyo (magistrate of temples) under Tario (chief minister) Naosuke II, then became Osaka jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle).

sen.j: 京都所司代に任命されたが、朝廷内から大原重徳を中心に安政の大獄の当事者の起用に反対が起こった。
sen.e: Thus, when he was he was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai (local governor of Kyoto) after Osaka jodai, the Imperial court centered on Shigetomi OHARA was against Munehide because he conducted the Ansei Purge.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, when he was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai (local governor of Kyoto) after being Osaka jodai, the Imperial court centered around Shigetomi OHARA was against Munehide because of his role in conducting the Ansei Purge.

Thus, when he was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai (local governor of Kyoto) after being Osaka jodai, the Imperial Court centered around Shigetomi OHARA was against Munehide because of his role in conducting the Ansei Purge.
sen.cmt: Court大文字にしました。一原文一訳文の例外対処のため、原文の文末を訂正しました。

sen.j: また幕府内でも会津藩主・松平容保が反対したた。
sen.e: And also, the lord of Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA who was on the side of bakufu was against him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And also, the lord of Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA who was on the side of bakufu was against him.
And also, the lord of Aizu Domain Katamori MATSUDAIRA who was on the side of bakufu was against him.

sen.j: そのため、任命はされたが赴任ができず、2ヶ月後に更迭された。
sen.e: Therefore, even though Munehide was appointed as the Kyoto shoshidai, he couldn't take the new post and two months later he was replaced.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, even though Munehide was appointed as the Kyoto shoshidai, he couldn't take the new post and two months later he was replaced.
Therefore, even though Munehide was appointed as the Kyoto shoshidai, he couldn't take the new post and two months later he was replaced.

sen.j: 代償として溜詰格となり譜代大名最高の格式を得たが、安政の大獄に対する追罰人事を受け、その格式は約1年3ヶ月で剥奪された。
sen.e: Instead, he was conferred Tamarizume kaku (the highest rank of the government), and got the highest rank of Fudai daimyo (hereditary feudal lord), but he was stripped of his rank as punishment for the Ansei Purge 15 months later.

Instead, he was conferred Tamarizume kaku (the highest rank of the government), and got the highest rank of Fudai daimyo (hereditary feudal lord), but he was stripped of his rank as punishment for the Ansei Purge 15 months later.

Instead, he was conferred Tamarizume kaku (the highest rank of the government), and got the highest rank of Fudai daimyo (hereditary feudal lord), but he was stripped of his rank as punishment for the Ansei Purge 15 months later.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました

sen.j: その後、老中となり、在任中の慶応2年（1866年）の第二次長州征伐では安芸国広島に出陣し、幕軍の指揮を執った。
sen.e: After that, Munehide became the Roju (elder councilor) and in the event of the Second conquest of Choshu in 1866, went battling to Hiroshima, Aki Province and conducted the bakufu's army.
After that, Munehide became the Roju (elder councilor) and in the event of the Second conquest of Choshu in 1866, wen to battle in Hiroshima, Aki Province and conducted the bakufu's army.
After that, Munehide became the Roju (elder councilor) and in the event of the Second conquest of Choshu in 1866, went to battle in Hiroshima, Aki Province and conducted the bakufu's army.

sen.j: やがて戦争継続の不利を悟り、捕虜にしていた長州藩の宍戸・小田村両家老を独断で釈放し、有利な和平工作を試みた。
sen.e: He realized that continuing battle was disadvantageous and tried to release captives Shishido and Odamura who were chief retainers of Choshu Domain on his own to make a peace overture advantageously.

He realized that continuing the battle was disadvantageous and tried to release captives Shishido and Odamura on his own, who were the chief retainers of the Choshu Domain and attempted to create an advantageous peace pact.

He realized that continuing the battle was disadvantageous and tried to release captives Shishido and Odamura on his own, who were the chief retainers of the Choshu Domain and attempted to create an advantageous peace pact.

sen.j: だがこれが発覚し、老中を罷免され、隠居謹慎を命ぜられた。
sen.e: However, his plot was found out and he was dismissed from the Roju and was confined to his house.
However, his plot was found out and he was dismissed from the Roju and confined to his house.
However, his plot was found out and he was dismissed from the Roju and confined to his house.

sen.j: 家督は五男・宗武に譲った。
sen.e: He ceded the family estate to his fifth son Munetake.
He ceded the family estate to his fifth son Munetake.
He ceded the family estate to his fifth son Munetake.

sen.j: 維新後は新政府に出仕し，伊勢神宮の大宮司などを歴任した。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, he served for the new government and worked as the Daiguji (the Supreme Priest) of Ise-jingu Shrine.
After the Meiji Restoration, he served for the new government and worked as the Daiguji (the Supreme Priest) of Ise-jingu Shrine.
After the Meiji Restoration, he served for the new government and worked as the Daiguji (the Supreme Priest) of Ise-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 明治6年（1874年）に65歳で没。
sen.e: He died in 1874 at the age of 65.
He died in 1874 at the age of 65.
He died in 1874 at the age of 65.

sen.j: 1809年（文化 (元号)6年） 生誕
sen.e: He was born in 1809.
He was born in 1809.
He was born in 1809.

sen.j: 1841年（天保11年） 家督相続（11月4日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: He inherited the family estate on November 4, 1841 (lunar calendar).
He inherited the family estate on November 4, 1841 (lunar calendar).
On November 27, 1840, he inherited the family estate.

sen.j: 1842年（天保12年） 奏者番
sen.e: Appointed as Sojaban (officer who conducted a ceremony).
Appointed as Sojaban (officer who conducted a ceremony).
In 1842, appointed as Sojaban (officer who conducted a ceremony).

sen.j: 1844年（天保14年） 奏者番免ぜられる
sen.e: Dismissed Sojaban in 1844.
Dismissed Sojaban in 1844.
In 1844, dismissed Sojaban.

sen.j: 1846年（弘化3年） 奏者番（再役）
sen.e: Reappointed as Sojaban in 1846.
Reappointed as Sojaban in 1846.
In 1846, reappointed as Sojaban.

sen.j: 1858年（安政5年） 寺社奉行兼任（10月9日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: Appointed as Jisha bugyo on October 9, 1858 (lunar calendar) concurrently.
Appointed as Jisha bugyo on October 9, 1858 (lunar calendar) concurrently.
On November 14, 1858, appointed as Jisha bugyo concurrently.

sen.j: 1860年（万延元年） 奏者番兼寺社奉行免ぜられ（12月26日 (旧暦)）、大坂城代拝命（12月28日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: He was dismissed Sojaban and Jisha bugyo on December 26, 1860 (lunar calendar) and was appointed as Osaka Jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle) on December 28 (lunar calendar).
He was dismissed Sojaban and Jisha bugyo on December 26, 1860 (lunar calendar) and was appointed as Osaka Jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle) on December 28 (lunar calendar).
On February 5, 1861, he was dismissed Sojaban and Jisha bugy and, on February 7, he was appointed as Osaka Jodai (deputy castellan of Osaka Castle).

sen.j: 1862年（文久2年） 大坂城代免、同日、京都所司代拝命（6月30日 (旧暦)）、所司代免（8月24日 (旧暦)）、溜間詰格
sen.e: In 1862, he was dismissed Osaka jodai and was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai on June 30, but he was dismissed Kyoto Shoshidai on August 24 and conferred Tamarizume kaku.
In 1862, he was dismissed Osaka jodai and was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai on June 30, but he was dismissed Kyoto Shoshidai on August 24 and conferred Tamarizume kaku.
On July 26, 1862, he was dismissed Osaka jodai and was appointed as Kyoto Shoshidai, but, on September 17, he was dismissed Kyoto Shoshidai and conferred Tamarizume kaku.

sen.j: 1863年（文久3年） 溜間詰格から伺候席に降格（11月23日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: In 1863, he was demoted from Tamarizume kaku to Shikoseki (common room) rank on November 23 (lunar calendar).
In 1863, he was demoted from Tamarizume kaku to Shikoseki (common room) rank on November 23 (lunar calendar).
On January 2, 1864, he was demoted from Tamarizume kaku to Shikoseki (common room) rank.

sen.j: 1864年（元治元年） 老中（8月18日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: In 1864, appointed as Roju on August 18 (lunar calendar).
In 1864, appointed as Roju on August 18 (lunar calendar).
On September 18, 1864, appointed as Roju.

sen.j: 1866年（慶応2年） 老中免職（7月25日 (旧暦)）、隠居
sen.e: In 1866, he was dismissed from the Roju and was confined to his house on July 25 (lunar calendar).
In 1866, he was dismissed from the Roju and was confined to his house on July 25 (lunar calendar).
On September 3, 1866, he was dismissed from the Roju and was confined to his house.
He died on December 20, 1873.
He died on December 20, 1873.
He died on December 20, 1873.

sen.j: 墓所
sen.e: Burial place
Burial place
Burial place

sen.j: 天神境内（京都府宮津市万町）
sen.e: Temple grounds on Tenjin (Yorozu-machi, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture)
Temple grounds on Tenjin (Yorozu-machi, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture)
Temple grounds on Tenjin (Yorozu-machi, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture).
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 大頂寺（京都府宮津市金屋谷）
sen.e: Daicho-ji Temple (Kanayadani, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture)
Daicho-ji Temple (Kanayadani, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture)
Daicho-ji Temple (Kanayadani, Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture)
